Loved That Tiger
Monster Rancher Metropolis: Library: Fan Fiction, Poetry, Birthday List, Links & Non-Fiction Archive: Poetry: Loved That Tiger
By RaystormX on Friday, March 18, 2005 - 11:20 pm:

Inspired by my tiger (tiger/tiger) fang, and the book, "love that dog"

We were outside
In the Market
Me and some other Breeders
Playing with my monster
Throwing around a ball
Before dinner
And Fang was
Chasing chasing chasing
With his feet going
Every which way
And his tail
Wag wag wagging
And his mouth
Slob slob slobbering
And he was
All over the place
Smiling and wagging
And slobbering
And making
Us laugh
And my dad
Came walking up the Market street
He was way down there
Near the end
I could see him
After he got off the baku
and he was walk walk walking
and I saw him wave
and he called out
“hey there, son!”
and so I didn’t see
the Zan
coming from the other way
until someone else
one of the breeders
called out
“Zan!!”
and I turned around
and I saw a
black zan black zan
splattered with blood
speeding down the road
and I saw fang going after the ball
his tail
wag wag wagging
and I called him
“Fang!Fang!”
but it was too late
because the
black zan black zan
splattered with blood
speeding down the road
Slashed Fang
Slish Slash Slice
And kept on going
In such a hurry
So fast
So many miles to go
It wouldn’t even stop
And
Fang
Was just there
In the road
Lying on his side
With his legs bent funny
And his side heaving
And I said
“Fang!Fang!Fang!”
and then my dad
was there
and he lifted Fang
out of the road
and laid him on the grass
and
Fang
never
opened
his
eyes
again…
Ever.

By RaystormX on Tuesday, March 22, 2005 - 03:43 pm:

I didn't say you HAD to comment, I just wanna know what you think. kinda like how a baker wants to know how good his cake is.

By Anonymous on Wednesday, March 23, 2005 - 11:44 am:

I'm not really into non rhyming poetry unless it has strong imagery or symbolism in it, free verse has always seemed, IMHO, to be a form of essay writing when done badly.

Why use that repeating word scheme? Its gimmicky and its inconsistently applied throughout the piece. The black zan splattered with blood running down the road is also repeated, rather needlessly i think, since the reader already knows that and then you repeat it again, why? It just adds length without strengthening the image or the emotion you're trying to evoke. Also I think its a bit long, and you could probably tighten it up by excising some unecessary words.

I don't know if that helps. Just my two cents.

By RaystormX on Wednesday, March 23, 2005 - 04:21 pm:

...i just got it from this one book, "love that dog" and that's just the way it was made. all i did was change some words. jeez, didnt know it sux that badly. -__-;; and no. it doesnt help.
